stem: A 31-year-old client at 36 weeks gestation arrives at the triage unit reporting sudden, agonizing abdominal pain. Based on the documentation in the Maternal-Fetal Assessment & Pain Log tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Acute obstetric emergency.
Background: G3P2. History of chronic hypertension and tobacco use.
Assessment: Client reports constant, 'tearing' abdominal pain. Small amount of dark red vaginal bleeding noted.
Recommendation: Immediate surgical and neonatal standby.

tabs.title: Maternal-Fetal Physical Exam
tabs.content:
Assessment ItemFindingInterpretation
Uterine ToneBoard-like; Tense; No relaxationConcealed Hemorrhage suspected
Fetal Heart Rate105 bpm (Bradycardia)Fetal Distress
FHR VariabilityAbsent; Recurrent Late DecelerationsHypoxia
Vaginal BleedingScant; Dark RedNon-reassuring

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 158/104 (previously 130/80), HR 122, RR 26, SpO2 96% on RA.

actionOptions.text: Prepare the client for an emergent Cesarean section
Establish a large-bore (16-18 gauge) IV access for fluid resuscitation
Place the client in a high-Fowler's position to ease breathing
Perform a digital vaginal exam to determine cervical dilation

parameterOptions.text: Continuous fetal heart rate monitoring for distress
Signs of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) (Oozing from IV site)
Hourly measurement of serum uric acid

rationale.correct: This is a classic presentation of Placental Abruption (c2): Agonizing pain, dark red bleeding, 'board-like' uterine rigidity, and fetal distress (late decels/bradycardia). The risk factors (HTN, tobacco) support this. Priority actions include preparing for immediate delivery to save the fetus (a1) and aggressive volume replacement for the mother (a2). Monitoring fetal status (p1) and watching for DIC (p2)—a common complication of abruption where clotting factors are consumed—is essential.
clinicalPearls: A board-like abdomen is the most significant finding; it indicates that blood is trapped behind the placenta, irritating the uterine muscle.
NEVER perform a vaginal exam on a client with undiagnosed vaginal bleeding until Previa is ruled out by ultrasound.

questionTrap.trap: Performing a vaginal exam when you see blood.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: If the cause of bleeding isn't known, putting your finger in the cervix could poke through a low-lying placenta (Previa) and cause fatal hemorrhage. Avoid exams!

mnemonic.title: Abruption vs Previa
mnemonic.expansion: Abruption = Awful pain. Previa = Primarily painless.
